paragraphs.name: 03b8
paragraphs.text: Bill Higgins is a Distinguished Engineer at IBM based in Raleigh, North Carolina, USA. The above article is personal and does not necessarily represent IBM’s positions, strategies or opinions.

paragraphs.name: dd18
paragraphs.text: It’s hard to compress two and a half years of experience into an article, but what I described above is the gist of what I learned. Before closing, I thought I’d share list some important details that support the above approach.

We did not perform thorough analysis to select the early tools, yet they’ve been wildly successful inside IBM. Did we get lucky? Nope – the secret is that we had good taste in who we followed [5]. One major lesson I’ve learned from our IBM CIO Jeff Smith is “find what best looks like, and learn from it” [6]. We looked around the company and around the tech industry for people who we thought were “doing it right” and simply asked them what tools they were using and why. Some tools and practices kept coming up again and again, with compelling success stories, so we went for those.
paragraphs.name: 254f

paragraphs.text: Being in the group of IBMers you reference who saw what was going on and latched on to the new ways of working I am still amazed at two things: (1) how much productivity can be gained by adopting a new workflow along with the associated shift in mindset, processes, and tools and (2) how many people still resist the change. ce20d6bee9e5.title: Bill Higgins, thank you for this amazing post!

paragraphs.text: Bill Higgins, thank you for this amazing post! The message is important one for all professionals to engage. The theme of continual learning cannot be overstated and “looking outside your company” is excellent perspective to never lose sight of. Pay attention to “what is happening around you…”. Always.

3ee2502dc98.title: Great article Bill, thanks for sharing.

paragraphs.text: Great article Bill, thanks for sharing. A warning though, just as “culture eats strategy for breakfast,” organizational structure eats culture for lunch! Culture is an emergent property of organization design. You might be interested in reading this: https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/antifragile-heteroticorganisations-jc-wandemberg-boschetti-ph-d-
